awd_titl_txt: RoadMAPPs to Careers:  A New Approach to Mobile Apps Education featuring a Mapp for Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing Students
awd_abstract_narration:
RoadMAPPS to CAREERS will help solve a significant projected skills gap in the US economy.  As smart phones, smart things, tablets and wearable devices continue to change the way we communicate, do business and access information, the demand for mobile applications has grown exponentially.  This explosive increase in demand translates into a large skills gap - there are simply more mobile application (app) development job openings than there are skilled application developers to fill them. The Bureau of Labor Statistics predicts that there will be approximately 82,000 mobile app developer jobs for candidates with associate degrees by 2020.  The RoadMAPPS to Careers project will prepare associate degree students for mobile app developer positions that pay well above the national average, maintain a high rate of employment, and offer a range of advancement opportunities.  The 5-semester curriculum is being developed and initially offered at the National Technical Institute for the Deaf (NTID), one of the nine colleges of the Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT).  The program content and educational strategies of the curriculum are appropriate for all students, whether hearing or deaf, and can be tailored for programs requiring less than five semesters.  However, specific teaching techniques tailored to the needs of deaf and hard-of-hearing students will be employed at NTID.  The project will also create a pathway to the program for middle and high school students through career awareness materials, summer camp activities and dual credit courses.  

The broad scope of the curriculum will integrate technical courses with business courses, general education courses, and work experiences in order to cultivate the technical, social, and work skills needed for success in today's global economy. Students will learn through instruction, hands-on exercises, labs, and learning support community activities.  They will also fulfill a required cooperative work experience and complete a capstone project where they will design and develop a publishable mobile app.  Although other colleges are offering programs in mobile app development, RoadMAPPS to Careers will introduce an innovative cross-platform approach that is especially appropriate for an associate degree program.  Students will learn the programming concepts and acquire the skills needed to create mobile apps that run on multiple platforms (iOS, Android and Windows) without being overwhelmed by learning a different programming language for each platform.  A leading developer of cross-platform technology (Xamarin) is partnering with RIT on the project.  Students will also have the opportunity to achieve C# and Xamarin certification, which are standards in the field.

por.por_cntn:
The industry-driven RoadMAPP's to Careers: A New Approach to Mobile Apps Education featuring a Mapp for Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing Students project was established to increase the number of deaf and hard-of-hearing students pursuing IT-related careers through the development and implementation of an AAS degree in mobile application development for deaf and hard-of-hearing students. 

With the significant input and active involvement of our corporate partners, a five semester AAS degree program was developed and implemented comprised of 76 semester credits, of which 49 are technical (major) credits, 24 are Liberal Arts and Science credits and three (3) are open elective credits.  The program focuses on the use of Microsoft Xamarin as the cross-platform development tool for creating innovative apps.   

Our corporate partners worked with us to develop and teach 10 new technical courses for the program.  Further they worked with us as "clients" for our Mobile App Development Capstone Projects course and provided leads and opportunites for our required summer student co-op work experience program.  By the time the students graduate, they will have published an app to both the Google Play and Apple stores. 

Although the program content was developed and implemented for deaf and hard-of hearing students, the content and educational strategies of the curriculum is approapriate for all students whether hearing or deaf.  Lecture material, labs, hands-on activites and learning support community activities are all available through our GitHub link.   

This project has served to create a pipeline for deaf and hard-of-hearing students interested in pursuing an Information Technology (IT) education.  Multiple summer camp offerings for junior high through high school ages have provided experiences where students can better understand the nature of work, career opportunities and employment possibilities with a education in mobile application development.  Creating the self-confidence and identity as (deaf) Mobile App professionals, will positively impact the number of diverse workers in the mobile application development field.  The skills attained have prepared the deaf students for entry level employment as application developers, web/mobile designers and/or developers and computer programmers.  

Below are the project outcomes:

Student Outcome:

1)     240 Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing Junior High School (7th, 8th and 9th grade) students from across the US attended Tech Boyz and Tech Girlz, where they experienced coding (many for the first time), and learned about mobile app development careers.

2)     275 Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing 10th and 11th graders attended an Explore your Future summer camp and received

3)     720 Deaf and Hard of Hearing students entering the National Technical Institute for the Deaf were exposed to the mobile app development career with more than 150 expressing interest in learning more about it through sampling exercises where they learned basic programming and app development. 

4)     150+ participated in basic programming and app development exercises

5)     30 chose to start the Mobile App Development program as their program of choice to study.

6)     11 students successfully completed a co-op work experience.

7)     11 students graduated from the Mobile App Development program.

8)     11 students continued their education for a BS degree in Web and Mobile Computing at RIT.

9)     Two of the 11 students so far have graduated from the BS degree in Web and Mobile Computing and have entered the workforce as Mobile App Developers.

The network of graduates that is emerging from this program is yielding a pool of mentors, advisors and professionals for the next generation of mobile app developers.

 

Program and Course Development Outcome:

1) The 76 credit hour program was implemented and 10 courses were fully developed from scratch. (see attached image)

Since the initial development of the 10 courses, (including lecture material, lab exercises, homework assignments, test and quiz material and app development projects), all courses have been modified and updated for currency.  The 10 developed courses include:

Programming Fundamentals I: Mobile Domain

Programming Fundamentals II: Mobile Domain

Survey of Emerging Visual Design

Software Analysis and Design

Mobile User Experience

Mobile App Development I

Mobile User Experience

Mobile App Development II

Web Services and Storage Technologies

Mobile App Development Capstone Projects

 

Student Learning Community Outcomes:

54 Student Learning Community events were conducted.  These included activities in broad topics such as Relationship Building, Developing Good Study Habits, Team Building, Learn and Create Series, Special Speaker Series, Career Path Discussions, Competitions and Engagement with Professionals in the field.  (see attached schedul of events)

 

Industry Partner Engagement:

Between 2015 and the end of the grant period, we hosted three program advisory board meetings and one mini-conference.  

 

Dissemmination of Materials:

In May of 2021, we hosted a Mobile App Development Mini-Conference at which time, we provided course materials to attendees via GitHub: https://github.com/MAD-NTID/RoadMAPPs-Project. 


Last Modified: 09/01/2021
Modified by: Brian Trager
